165.01 SHORT TITLE.
This Title shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the Zoning Code
or Zoning Regulations.
165.02 DEFINITIONS.
The following words and phrases whenever used in the ordinances of the City,
shall be construed as defined in this section unless, from the context, a
different meaning is intended or unless different meaning is specifically
defined and more particularly directed to the use of such words or phrases:
1.    Words beginning with A.
   A.    Accessory buildings means a subordinate building which is incidental
to and customary in connection with the principal building or use and which is
located on the same lot with such principal building or use.
   B.    Accessory use means a subordinate use which is incidental to and
customary in connection with the principal building or use and which is located
on the same lot with such principal building or use.
2.    Words beginning with B.
   A.    Basement means a story having part but not more than one-half of its
height below grade. A basement is counted as a story for the purpose of height
regulation if subdivided and used for dwelling purposes other than by a janitor
employed on the premises.
   B.    Bed and breakfast home means any dwelling used for accommodation of
overnight guests for a fee or for the service of food and beverages to
overnight guests for a fee.
   C.    Blade sign see projecting sign.
   D.    Boarding house see lodging house.
   E.    Building means any structure having a roof supported by columns or
walls built for the support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals,
chattel, or property of any kind, but not including any vehicle, trailer, with
or without wheels, nor any movable device, such as furniture, machinery, or
equipment. When any portion of a building is completely separated from any
other portion thereof by a division wall without openings or by a fire wall,
then each such portion shall be deemed to be a separate building.
   F.    Building, height of means the vertical distance from the grade to the
highest point of the coping of a flat roof, or to the deck line of a mansard
roof, or to the mean height level between eaves and ridge for gable, hip, and
gambrel roof.
   G.    Building Official means the individual designated by the City Manager
to administer this Zoning Code and who is responsible for the enforcement of
the regulations imposed by this Code .
3.    Words beginning with C.
   A.    Cellar means a story having more than one-half of its height below
grade.
   B.    Clinic means an establishment where patients are not lodged overnight,
but are admitted for examination and treatment by a group of physicians or
dentists practicing medicine together.
   C.    Core central business district mean the four block area with the
perimeter defined by Quarry, Olive, Pleasant and Second Streets.
4.    Words beginning with D.
   A.    Deck means a structure with no roof and no walls.
   B.    Directional sign means any on-premise sign that includes information
assisting in the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic such as enter, exit,
one way, no-parking, etc.
   C.    Domesticated animals means animals which are raised, tended, groomed,
maintained, boarded, or kept for the purpose of commercial gain or for hobby
purposes with the exception of pets.
   D.    Dwelling means any building or portion thereof which is used
exclusively for residential purposes. A dwelling shall be on a permanent
foundation with no wheels, axles, or hitches, and shall be connected to the
City sewer and water system. A dwelling shall be at least 20 feet in width and
have a minimum floor area of 800 square feet. The owner of any building
classified as a dwelling shall surrender the title, if one exists, to the
County Assessor and request that the dwelling be listed as real estate.
   E.    Dwelling, Single - Family means a building designed to be occupied
exclusively by one family.
   F.    Dwelling, Multiple means a building designed for or occupied
exclusively by more than two families.
   G.    Dwelling, Two - Family means a building designed to be occupied
exclusively by two families.
   H.   intended to be occupied as separate living quarters by a single -
family as defined herein.
5.    Words beginning with E.
   A.    Enclosed porch means a structure with a roof and with walls.
6.    Words beginning with F.
   A.    Factory-built home means any home which is, wholly or in substantial
part, made, fabricated, formed, or assembled in manufacturing facilities for
installation or assembly and installation, on a building site. Factory-built
homes include mobile homes, manufactured homes, and modular homes.
   B.    Family means one or more persons related by blood, marriage, or
adoption occupying a dwelling unit as an individual housekeeping organization.
A family may include not more than two persons not related by blood, marriage,
or adoption.
   C.    Farm means an area exceeding 10 acres used for the purpose of growing
agricultural products or raising domesticated animals and accessory uses.
Farming does not include livestock operations which can be described as
feedlots; confinement areas; sale barns; or holding, transfer, or sale
stations.
   D.    Feather flag sign means a teardrop banner sign used as a temporary
sign.
   E.    Filling stations means any building or premises used for the retail
sale of motor vehicle fuels or accessory oils, fluids, etc. Accessory repair
services are included uses provided the premises are not used for storage of
wrecked or junked motor vehicles for periods exceeding 30 days.
   F.    Floor area means the total number of square feet of floor space within
the exterior walls of a building, not including space in cellars or basements;
however, if the cellar or basement is used for business or commercial purposes,
it shall be counted as floor area in computing off - street parking
requirements.
   G.    Frontage means the measure of a parcel that lies in direct contact
with a public street.
7.    Words beginning with G.
   A.    Garage, private means a detached accessory building, or portion of the
main building, housing the automobiles of the occupants of the premises.
   B.    Garage, public means any building or premises used as a business to
repair, sell or trade motor vehicles, except no wrecked or junked motor
vehicles may be stored outside for more than 30 days.
   C.    Grade means the average level of the finished surface of the ground
adjacent to the exterior walls of the building, except when any wall
approximately parallels and is not more than five feet from a street line, then
the elevation of the street at the center of the wall adjoining the street
shall be grade.
8.    Words beginning with H.
   A.    Home occupation means any business, profession, occupation, or trade
conducted for gain or support within a residential building or an accessory
structure thereto which is incidental and secondary to the use of such a
building for dwelling purposes and which does not change the essential
residential character of such building.
   B.    Hotel means a building in which lodging is provided and offered to the
public for compensation, and which is open to transient guests, in
contradistinction to a boarding house or lodging house as herein defined.
9.    Words beginning with I.
   A.    Institution means a building occupied by a nonprofit corporation or a
nonprofit establishment for public use.
10.    Words beginning with J.
11.    Words beginning with K.
12.    Words beginning with L.
   A.    Lodging house means a building or place where lodging and boarding is
provided, or which is equipped regularly to provide lodging and boarding by
pre-arrangement for definite periods, for compensation, for three or more, but
not exceeding 12 individuals, not open to transient guests, in
contradistinction to hotels open to transients.
   B.    Lot means a parcel of land occupied or intended for occupancy by a use
permitted in this Zoning Code, including one main building together with its
accessory buildings, open spaces and parking spaces required by this Code, and
having its principal frontage upon a street.
   C.    Lot, corner shall mean a lot abutting upon two or more streets at
their intersection.
   D.    Lot, depth of shall mean the horizontal distance between the front and
rear lot lines.
   E.    Lot, double frontage means a lot having frontage on two
nonintersecting streets, as distinguished from a corner lot.
   F.    Lot of record means lot or parcel of land, the deed of which has been
recorded in the office of the County Recorder prior to the adoption of this
Zoning Code.
13.    Words beginning with M.
   A.    Manufactured home lot means a lot within a manufactured home park for
the placement of a single factory-built home and the exclusive use of its
occupants.
   B.    Manufactured home means a factory-built home under authority of 42
U.S.C. Section 5403, that is required by federal law to display a seal from the
United States Department of Housing and Urban Development and was constructed
on or after June 15, 1976.
   C.    Manufactured home park means a site, lot, field, or tract of land upon
which three or more factory-built homes are placed on developed spaces and
operated as a for-profit enterprise with water, sewer or septic, and electrical
services available.
   D.    Manufacturing means the process of taking any number of raw or
finished materials and producing a finished product not intended for retail
sale on the premises.
   E.    Mobile home means any vehicle without motive power used or so
manufactured or constructed as to permit its being used as a conveyance upon
the public streets and highways and so designed, constructed, or reconstructed
as will permit the vehicle to be used as a place for human habitation by one or
more persons; but shall also include any such vehicle with motive power not
registered as a motor vehicle in the State. Mobile homes were constructed
before June 15, 1976.
   F.    Monument sign means any sign supported by a foundation, uprights, or
braces placed in the ground. Such a sign is not supported by any building. This
type of sign is in contact with the ground and is not elevated by a pole or
poles.
   G.    Motel, motor court, motor lodge, or tourist court means any building
or group of buildings containing guest rooms or dwelling units, some, or all of
which have a separate entrance leading directly from the outside of the
building with garage or parking space conveniently located on the lot, and
designed, used, or intended wholly or in part for the accommodation of
automobile transients.
14.    Words beginning with N.
   A.    Nonconforming use shall mean any building or land lawfully occupied
for a use at the time of passage of this Zoning Code or amendment thereto which
does not conform after the passage of this Zoning Code or amendment thereto
with the use regulation of the district in which it is situated.
   B.    Nursing home means a home for the aged or infirm, in which three or
more persons not of the immediate family are received, kept, or provided with
food and shelter or care, for compensation; but not including hospitals,
clinics, or similar institutions.
15.    Words beginning with O.
   A.    Obsolete sign means any sign that advertises a business, lessee,
owner, product, service, or activity that is no longer located on the premises
where the sign is displayed.
16.    Words beginning with P.
   A.    Parking space means an area sufficient in size to store an automobile
together with a driveway connecting the space to the street. For all uses
except in a residential district, the term parking space shall include
sufficient area to permit maneuvering into and out of the space. The
maneuvering area or parking area may not include public walkways.
   B.    Patio or terrace means a paved area or platform no more than 12 inches
above the ground.
   C.    Permanent sign means a sign that does not advertise a single event
such as a yard sale, an electoral campaign, a real estate sale, or a special
event such as a church or civic festival. A permanent sign is made of materials
intended for long-term use. Permanent signs include, but are not limited to:
wall signs, monument, free-standing signs, pole signs, projecting signs, and
roof signs.
   D.    Pets means any animal maintained or capable of being kept in the home
for noncommercial, personal enjoyment. For the purposes of this Zoning Code,
pets shall not include domesticated animals normally thought of as farm or
ranch animals including cows, pigs, horses, chickens, ducks, turkeys, geese,
other fowl, goats, or sheep; nor shall it include any animal normally thought
of as wild.
   E.    Pole sign means any sign that is mounted on a freestanding pole,
poles, or other support so that the bottom edge of the sign face(s) is above
grade. A billboard sign is a type of pole sign.
   F.    Porch means a structure with a roof and no walls.
   G.    Premises means a lot, together with all buildings and structures
thereon.
   H.    Projecting sign means a sign for commercial structures, which is
suspended from a mounting attached directly to the building wall, hangs
perpendicular to the building wall, and possibly extends into a public right-
of-way.
17.    Words beginning with Q.
18.    Words beginning with R.
   A.    Required rear yard means that portion of the rear yard, extended
forward from the rear lot line, which comprises the minimum setback distance
for the zone in which it is located.
   B.    Roof sign means a sign erected or constructed wholly upon or over the
roof of a building and supported on the roof structure.
19.    Words beginning with S.
   A.    Satellite devices means any device designed to receive, transmit, or
translate signals from television, other satellites, or other broadcasting
devices for home and personal use. For the purposes of this Zoning Code,
residential use of satellite devices shall be considered accessory buildings
and subject to all regulations that apply to accessory buildings. Area taken up
by satellite devices shall be computed by squaring the largest width.
Commercial use of satellite devices are special uses.
   B.    Setback means the distance required to obtain minimum front, side, or
rear yard space requirements as measured from the property line as required by
this Zoning Code.
   C.    Sign means an identification, description, illustration, or device
which is affixed to or represented directly or indirectly upon a building,
structure, or land, and which directs attention to a product, place, activity,
person, institution, or business.
   D.    Story means that portion of a building, other than a cellar, included
between the surface of any floor and the surface of the floor next above it or,
if there be no floor above it, then the space between the floor and the ceiling
next above it.
   E.    Story, half means a space under a sloping roof which has the line of
intersection of roof decking and wall face not more than three feet above the
top floor level, and in which space not more than 60 percent of the floor area
is finished off for use. A half story may be used for occupancy only in
conjunction with and by the occupancy of the floor immediately below.
   F.    Street means a public way which affords the principal means of access
to abutting property.
   G.    Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which
requires permanent location on the ground; or attached to something having a
permanent location on the ground and including, but not limiting, the
generality of the foregoing, advertising signs, billboards, backstops for
tennis courts, and pergolas.
   H.    Structural alteration means any change except those required by law or
this Code, that would prolong the life of the supporting members of a building
or structure, such as bearing walls, columns, beams, or girders, not including
openings in bearing walls as permitted by other regulations.
20.    Words beginning with T.
   A.    Temporary sign means a sign that is not permanently affixed or
anchored to a structure of the ground for long-term use.
21.    Words beginning with U.
22.    Words beginning with V.
23.    Words beginning with W.
   A.    Wall sign means any sign attached parallel to a wall, painted on the
wall surface or, or erected and kept within the confines of an outside wall of
any building or structure, which is supported by such wall or building. Wall
signs do not include signs or lettering on doors or windows. Wall signs do not
include minor directional signs and similar.
   B.    Wind turbine means any structure that is supported, wholly or in part,
by the ground or another structure that is designed to harness, use, or store
energy from wind power.
   C.    Wind turbine height means the vertical distance measured from the base
of the structure to the top of the tallest blade when the blade is parallel and
extending over the base structure.
24.    Words beginning with X.
25.    Words beginning with Y.
   A.    Yard means an open space on the same lot with a building unoccupied
and unobstructed by any portion of the structure from the ground upward, except
as otherwise provided in this Zoning Code.
   B.    Yard, front means that portion of the full width of the lot that
exists from the street right-of-way to the closest structure. Corner lots have
two front yards, and must meet minimum set back requirements for each. Double
frontage lots shall have the street exposure closest to the main entrance of
the structure as the front yard.
   C.    Yard, rear means the yard extending the full width of the lot between
a main building and the rear lot line.
   D.    Yard, side means a yard between the main building and the side line of
the lot, and extending from the front yard line to the rear yard line.
26.    Words beginning with Z.
165.03 DISTRICTS.
In order to classify, regulate, and restrict the locations of trades,
industries, and the location of buildings designed for specified uses; to
regulate and limit the height and use of the lot areas; and to regulate and
determine the areas of yards, courts, and other open spaces surrounding such
buildings, the City is hereby divided into districts which shall be known as:
1.    A-1 Agricultural District.
2.    R-1 Residential District.
3.    R-2 General Residential District.
4.    R-3 General Residential District.
5.    B-1 General Business District.
6.    B-2 Central Business District.
7.    MH-1 Mobile Home Park District.
8.    I-1 Light Industrial District.
9.    I-2 Middle Industrial District.
10.    I-3 Heavy Industrial District.
165.04 DISTRICT MAP.
The boundaries of these districts are shown upon the District Map which
accompanies and is made a part of this Zoning Code. Said map and all the
information shown thereon shall have the same force and effect as if all was
fully set forth or described herein. The original of this map is properly
attested and is on file with the Clerk.
165.05 ZONING MAP CHANGES.
EDITOR'S NOTE
The Official Zoning map located in City Hall and amendments are in full
force and effect. The following ordinances have been adopted amending the
Official Zoning Map of the City and have not been codified herein, but are
specifically saved from repeal and are in full force and effect.

1154      June 17, 2019
1161      December 16, 2019
1199      September 16, 2022
1215      March 4, 2024

165.06 ANNEXATION.
All territory which may hereafter be annexed to the City, shall be classified
in the A-1 Agricultural District until, within a reasonable time after
annexation, the annexed territory shall be appropriately classified by
ordinance in accordance with Section
165.44.
165.07 VACATED PUBLIC WAYS.
Whenever any street or other public way is vacated by official action of the
City, the zoning district adjoining each side of such street or public way
shall be automatically extended to the center of such vacation and all area
included in the vacation shall then and henceforth be subject to all
appropriate regulations of the extended districts.
165.08 BOUNDARY RULES.
Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of the various
districts as shown on the District Map, the following rules shall apply:
1.    Where a boundary is given a position within a street, alley, or
nonnavigable stream, it shall be deemed to be in the center of the street,
alley, or stream, and if the actual location of such street, alley, or stream
varies slightly from the location as shown on the District Map, then the actual
location shall control.
2.    Where a boundary line is shown as being located a specific distance from
a street line or other physical feature, this distance shall control.
3.    Where a boundary line is shown adjoining or coincident with a railroad,
it shall be deemed to be in the center of the railroad right-of-way and
distances measured from a railroad shall be measured from the center of the
designated main line track.
4.    Where the district boundaries follow or approximately follow platted lot
lines or other property lines, the district boundaries shall be construed to
follow the platted lot lines or other property lines.
5.    In unsubdivided property, unless otherwise indicated, the district
boundary line shall be determined by the use of the scale contained on such
map.
165.09 EXCEPTIONS.
1.   No building or structure shall be erected, converted, enlarged,
reconstructed, moved, or structurally altered nor shall any building or land be
used except for the purpose permitted in the district in which the building or
land is located.
2.    No building or structure shall be erected, converted, enlarged,
reconstructed, moved, or structurally altered except in conformity with the
height, yard, area per family, parking, and other regulations prescribed herein
for the district in which the building is located.
3.    The minimum yards and other open spaces including lot area per family
required by this Zoning Code shall be provided for each and every building or
structure hereafter erected, and such minimum yards, open spaces, and lot areas
for each and every building or structure whether existing at the time of
passage of this Zoning Code or hereafter erected shall not be encroached upon
or be considered as a yard or open space requirement for any other building or
structure.
4.    Every building hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be located
on a lot abutting a public street that has been dedicated to and accepted by
the City, and in no case shall there be more than one main building on one lot
unless otherwise provided in this Zoning Code.
165.10 AGRICULTURAL DISTRICT (A-1).
1.    District Regulations. The regulations set forth in this section or set
forth elsewhere in this Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are the
regulations in the Agricultural District (A-1).
2.    Use Regulations. The Agricultural District is intended for use by
professional or amateur agriculturists who raise crops or livestock for profit
or hobby purposes. A building or premises shall be used for the following
purposes:
   A.   Residences of owner, operator, or hired help limited to a maximum of
three dwelling units.
   B.   Barns, sheds, or outbuildings for the storage of crops. Crops stored on
the premises shall be limited to crops grown by the owner or tenant on the
premises.
   C.   Barns, sheds, or outbuildings for the storage or repair of the owner's
or operator's farm equipment or machinery.
   D.   Commercial radio tower or satellite devices.
   E.   Landing field or strip for aircraft.
   F.   Riding stable when located on not less than 10 acres.
3.    Parking Regulations. Refer to Section
165.38.
4.    Height And Area Regulations.
   A.   Front Yards. Front yard setbacks for Agricultural District shall be 30
feet or two feet of lineal setback for every one foot of building height,
whichever is greater.
      (1)   Front yard regulations for dwellings in an industrial district are
the same as those in the R-1 Residential district.
   B.   Side Yards. Side yard setbacks for all industrial districts shall be
zero feet.
      (1)   Side yard regulations for dwellings in an industrial district are
the same as those in the R-1 Residential district.
   C.   Rear Yard. Rear yard setbacks for all industrial districts shall be 30
feet.
      (1)   Rear yard regulations for dwellings in an industrial district are
the same as those in the R-1 Residential district.
   D.   The front and rear yard regulations for commercial or non-industrial
use buildings in the Industrial Districts shall be the same as those setbacks
in the B-1 General Business District. No rear yards for commercial buildings
are required, except on the rear of a lot abutting an R-1 and R-2 Residential
District, in which event a rear yard of not less than 30 feet shall be
provided.
   E.   If a building contains both a business and industrial use in the
Industrial Districts, the industrial setback requirements shall prevail.
   F.   Existing business and commercial uses in existence in the Industrial
Districts at the time of the adoption of this Zoning Code shall be allowed to
continue and expand in their present location and shall not be considered as
non-conforming uses for the purposes of the enforcement of this Zoning Code.
165.11 RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT (R-1).
1.   Residential District (R-1). The regulations set forth in this section or
set forth elsewhere in this Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are
the regulations in the Residential District (R-1).
2.    Use Regulations:
   A.   A building or premises shall be used only for the following purposes:
      (1)   Single-family dwellings.
      (2)   Two-family dwellings.
      (3)   Churches.
      (4)   Public buildings, parks, playgrounds, community center, and
recreational vehicle campsites in City parks as designated by resolution of the
Council.
      (5)   Public schools, elementary and high, and private education
institutions having a curriculum the same as ordinarily given in public
schools, and having no rooms regularly used for housing and sleeping rooms.
      (6)   Home occupations.
      (7)   Golf courses, except miniature courses or practice driving tees
operated for commercial purposes.
      (8)   Temporary buildings, the uses of which are incidental to the
construction operations or sale of lots during development being conducted on
the same or adjoining tract or subdivision and which shall be removed upon
completion or abandonment of such construction, or upon the expiration of a
period of two years from the time of erection of such temporary buildings,
whichever is sooner.
      (9)   Cemetery or mausoleum on sites not less than 20 acres.
      (10)   Signs. Refer to Section
165.41.
      (11)   Accessory buildings and uses including, but not limited to,
accessory private garages, swimming pools, home barbecue grills, accessory
storage, and accessory off-street parking and loading space.
3.    Parking Regulations. Off-street parking spaces shall be provided in
accordance with the requirements for specific uses set forth in
Chapter 69 and Section
165.38.
4.    Height Regulations. No building shall exceed two and one-half stories nor
shall it exceed 35 feet except as provided in Section
165.20.
5.    Area Regulations.
   A.   Yard Regulations. Subject to the modifications set out in
Chapter 165, the regulations are as follows:
      (1)   Front Yard. There shall be a front yard of not less than 30 feet.
      (2)   Side Yard. There shall be a side yard on each side of a lot of not
less than seven feet.
      (3)   Rear Yard. There shall be a rear yard of not less than 30 feet.
      (4)   Front Porch Reconstruction. If a residence was constructed prior to
January 1, 1964, with a front porch that does not comply with the front yard or
side yard setback requirements, then the front porch may be rebuilt provided
that the overall square footage of the porch is not increased and the existing
nonconforming front and side yard setbacks are not decreased.
   B.   Minimum Lot Area.
      (1)   A lot occupied by a single-family dwelling shall contain not less
than 7,200 square feet and shall not be less than 60 feet in width.
      (2)   A lot occupied by a two-family dwelling shall contain not less than
9,000 square feet and shall not be less than 75 feet in width.
      (3)   A lot having an area or width less than herein required and which
was recorded under separate ownership from adjoining lots at the effective date
of this Zoning Code may be occupied by a single-family dwelling or by any other
permitted nonresidential use.
165.12 GENERAL RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT (R-2).
1.    District Regulations. The regulations set forth in this section or set
forth elsewhere in this Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are the
regulations of the General Residential District (R-2).
2.    Use Regulations. A building or premises shall be used only for the
following purposes:
   A.   Multiple - family dwellings.
   B.   Board and lodging houses.
   C.   Private clubs and lodges.
   D.   Hospitals, clinics, or institutions not primarily for the mentally ill
or those with contagious diseases, provided that less than 40 percent of the
total land area is occupied by buildings and that all the required yards are
increased by one foot for each one foot of building height in excess of height
limits as specified in this Zoning Code.
   E.   Hospitals, nursing homes, clinics, and educational, philanthropic, or
religious institutions, except for those for criminals or for the mentally ill.
   F.   Nursery school.
   G.   Any allowable use in the R-1 Residential District.
3.    Parking Regulations. Off-street parking spaces shall be provided in
accordance with the requirements for specific uses set out in
Chapter 69 and Section
165.38.
4.    Height Regulations. No building shall exceed two and one-half stories nor
shall it exceed 35 feet except as provided in Section
165.20.
5.    Area Regulations.
   A.   Yards. Subject to the modifications set out in
Chapter 165, the regulations are as follows:
      (1)   Front Yard. There shall be a front yard of not less than 30 feet.
      (2)   Side Yard. There shall be a side yard on each side of a lot of not
less than seven feet.
      (3)   Rear Yard. There shall be a rear yard of not less than 30 feet.
      (4)   Front Porch Reconstruction. If a residence was constructed prior to
January 1, 1964, with a front porch that does not comply with the front yard or
side yard setback requirements, then the front porch may be rebuilt provided
that the overall square footage of the porch is not increased and the existing
nonconforming front and side yard setbacks are not decreased.
   B.   Minimum Lot Area.
      (1)   A lot occupied by a single-family dwelling or a boarding or lodging
house shall contain not less than 6,000 square feet and shall be not less than
50 feet in width.
      (2)   A lot occupied by a two-family dwelling or a multiple-family
dwelling shall contain not less than 3,000 square feet for each dwelling unit
and shall be not less than 50 feet in width.
      (3)   A lot occupied by three or more dwelling units shall contain not
less than 1,500 square feet for each dwelling unit and shall be not less than
60 feet in width.
      (4)   A lot having an area or width less than herein required and which
was recorded under separate ownership from adjoining lots at the effective date
of this Zoning Code may be occupied by a single-family dwelling or by any other
permitted non-residential use.
165.13 GENERAL RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT (R-3).
1.   District Regulations. The regulations set forth in this section or set
forth elsewhere in this Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are the
regulations of the General Residential District (R-3).
2.    Use Regulations. A building or premises shall be used only for the
following purposes:
   A.   Any allowable use in the R-1 Residential District.
3.    Parking Regulations. Off-street parking spaces shall be provided in
accordance with the requirements for specific uses set out in Section
165.38.
4.    Height Regulations. No building shall exceed two and one-half stories nor
shall it exceed 35 feet except as provided in Section
165.20.
5.    Area Regulations.
   A.   Yard Regulations Subject to the modifications set out in
Chapter 165, the regulations are as follows:
      (1)   Front Yard. There shall be a front yard of not less than 30 feet.
      (2)   Side Yard. There shall be a side yard on each side of a lot of not
less than five feet.
      (3)   Rear Yard. There shall be a rear yard of not less than 30 feet.
   B.   Minimum Lot Area .
      (1)   A lot occupied by a single-family dwelling shall contain not less
than 7,200 square feet and shall not be less than 60 feet in width.
      (2)   A lot occupied by a two-family dwelling shall contain not less than
9,000 square feet and shall not be less than 75 feet in width.
      (3)   A lot having an area or width less than herein required and which
was recorded under separate ownership from adjoining lots at the effective date
of this Zoning Code may be occupied by a single-family dwelling or by any other
permitted nonresidential use.
165.14 MANUFACTURED HOME PARK DISTRICT (MH-1).
1.    District Regulations. The regulations set forth in this section or set
forth elsewhere in this Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are the
regulations in the Manufactured Home Park District (MH-1). See also
Chapter 147.
2.    Use Regulations. A building or premises within the Manufactured Home Park
District shall be used only for the following purposes:
   A.   Any use, including accessory buildings and uses, allowed in the R-
1 Residential District.
   B.   Manufactured home parks in accordance with the provisions of this
section and applicable State and federal laws and regulations.
   C.   No more than two permanent site-built dwellings shall be permitted in
any single manufactured home park.
   D.   Recreational facilities within a manufactured home park for exclusive
use of the occupants of the manufactured home park.
3.    Parking Regulations. Parking regulations relative to allowable uses
within the Manufactured Home Park District situated outside a manufactured home
park shall be as otherwise set forth in this Zoning Code. The following
regulations shall govern parking within a manufactured home park:
   A.   Two paved parking shall be provided on each manufactured home lot.
   B.   In addition, paved guest parking areas shall be provided throughout a
manufactured home park containing parking spaces at the rate of one parking
space per factory-built home within a manufactured home park, provided such
parking areas not be required when public streets or private drives serving the
interior of the manufactured home park are constructed at least 28 feet in
width.
   C.   Parking shall not be allowed on private drives less than 28 feet in
width.
   D.   Parking shall be allowed on one side only of private drives which are
at least 28 feet in width.
   E.   Parking shall be allowed on both sides of private drives which are at
least 32 feet in width.
   F.   Vehicles such as boats, boat trailers, travel trailers, pickup coaches,
truck tractors, trucks over one - ton pickup size, recreational vehicles, and
vehicles of a similar nature shall not be parked on a manufactured home lot,
guest parking area, or on a private drive or public street right-of-way within
a manufactured home park. Parking of the above-referenced vehicles shall be
confined to required storage lots.
4.    Street and Drive Requirements. Interior access may be provided by public
streets or private drives. Public streets shall be built to City standards.
When private drives are used, the following criteria shall apply:
   A.   Private drives shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete or
asphaltic concrete and shall be designed with adequate strength to accommodate
design loadings and shall include curb and gutter.
   B.   When off-street guest parking is not provided, private drives shall be
at least 24 feet wide.
   C.   When off-street guest parking is provided below, private drives shall
be at least 28 feet wide.
   D.   Cul-de-sac private drives shall not exceed 750 feet in length and shall
be provided with an outside roadway diameter of not less than 76 feet.
   E.   Intersecting private drives shall have centerlines as nearly straight
as possible. Jogs with centerline effects of more than five feet shall not be
permitted.
   F.   Intersections of private drives at angles less than 60 degrees shall
not be permitted.
   G.   If an intersection occurs at an angle other than a right angle, it
shall be rounded with a curve at a radius acceptable to the City Engineer.
   H.   Grades:
      (1)   Maximum - 10 percent.
      (2)   Minimum - five-tenths of a percent.
   I.   All private drives entering a public street must meet at a right angle
and be perpendicular to the public street for a minimum distance of 50 feet
without intersection of private drives. The intersecting private drive right-
of-way with the public street right-of-way shall be rounded with radii of not
less than 30 feet.
   J.   On any corner lot on which a front or side yard is required, no wall,
fence, sign, or other structure or no plant growth of a type which would
interfere with traffic visibility across the corner shall be permitted or
maintained higher than three feet above the curb level, within 15 feet of the
intersection of the edges of the private drives.
   K.   At least one access point onto a public street shall be provided for
each 100 manufactured home lots; street or drive connections to adjacent
properties may be required when deemed appropriate by the Zoning Administrator.
5.    Area Regulations. The following standards and criteria shall apply to all
manufactured home parks:
   A.   Screening. Permanent screening consisting of a masonry wall, wood
fence, landscaping material, or combination thereof shall be required around
the perimeter of a manufactured home park, except where the site is adjacent to
a public street right-of-way. The required screening shall have an opacity of
at least 80 percent year-round meaning if landscaping is used, the 80 percent
opacity shall be achieved within all four seasons. The required screening shall
be maintained in good order and not allowed to exist in a state of disrepair or
death. Fences or walls shall be at least eight feet in height but no taller
than 12 feet in height and shall be durable in nature or treated to prevent
deterioration. In the event a masonry wall or wood fence is used, landscaping
shall be placed between the wall or fence and the property line to form an
ornamental screen. Failure to maintain the required screening shall be
considered a violation of this section.
   B.   Yard Regulations .
      (1)   All manufactured home lots shall be at least 25 feet from all
perimeter property lines of the Manufactured Home Park District. The setback is
intended to be a landscaped open area. Parking, streets, drives, accessory
vehicles, and accessory uses shall not be allowed within the 25-foot setback
area.
      (2)   Each factory-built home within a manufactured home park shall be
set back at least 20 feet from any public street right-of-way or private drive
within the Manufactured Home Park District. Parking may be allowed within the
20-foot setback.
      (3)   Each manufactured home shall be set back at least 10 feet from all
manufactured home lot lines which are not abutting a public street right-of-way
or private drive. This setback shall not apply to parking areas, carports, and
other accessory buildings which are located on manufactured home lots which do
not border the perimeter of the Manufactured Home Park District.
      (4)   A private outdoor living area, such as a patio or deck, of at least
40 square feet shall be provided on each manufactured home lot adjoining the
factory-built home.
      (5)   Minimum Lot Area.
         a.    Each manufactured home lot shall contain at least 4,050 square
feet.
         b.    Each manufactured home lot shall be at least 45 feet wide at its
most narrow point.
6.    Miscellaneous Standards for Manufactured Home Parks.
   A.   Park Map. A map of the layout of the manufactured home park, of a scale
not greater than 1:50, showing the location of individual manufactured home
lots by number, shall be displayed on the park office building, or on the
identification sign at the entrance to the manufactured home park.
   B.   Sewer. Each manufactured home lot shall be provided with a sewer outlet
not less than four inches in diameter, connected to the main sewer system.
   C.   Lighting. Lighting shall be provided for all private streets, walkways,
buildings, and other facilities subject to nighttime use in accordance with
City requirements for residential streets and walkways.
   D.   Storage Lots. Each manufactured home park shall provide one or more
storage lots, in addition to required parking areas, for boats, boat trailers,
travel trailers, pickup coaches, truck tractors, trucks over one-ton pickup
size, recreational vehicles, and vehicles of a similar nature. The minimum area
required for storage lots shall be 200 square feet for each seven manufactured
home lots.
   E.   Sheds; Storage Buildings. Sheds or storage buildings may be located on
the same manufactured home lot as the factory-built structure it is intended to
serve. Such facilities shall be constructed of suitable weather resistant
materials.
   F.   Attached Enclosed Structures. Any enclosed structure attached to a
manufactured home shall be made out of compatible or similar exterior materials
and in conformance with City building codes. No structure shall be constructed
within 10 feet from the boundary line of any property which borders the
perimeter of the Manufactured Home Park District.
   G.   Landscaping. All yards and other open spaces not otherwise paved or
occupied by structures shall be landscaped and maintained.
   H.   Stormwater Management. A stormwater management system shall be designed
to minimize the possibility of soil erosion and flood damage on site and
downstream of a manufactured home park.
   I.   Fire Hydrants. No manufactured home, mobile home, site-built dwelling,
or other dwelling structure within a manufactured home park shall be situated
more than 650 feet from a fire hydrant .
7.    Existing Manufactured Home Lots; Nonconforming Uses.
   A.   Nonconforming Use. The lawful use of a manufactured home lot existing
at the time of the adoption of this subchapter and creation of the Manufactured
Home Park District may be continued even though such use does not conform with
the provisions of this section.
   B.   Restoration . In the event two-thirds of factory-built homes on
nonconforming manufactured home lots are damaged or destroyed by fire,
explosion, act of God, or the public enemy, the subject manufactured home lots
shall be restored in conformity with the regulations set forth in this section
provided discontinuance of the nonconformity is necessary for the safety of
life or property.
   C.   Lapse in Use . In the event the nonconforming use of a manufactured
home lot is discontinued for a period of at least one year, the use of the same
shall thereafter conform with the regulations set forth in this section.
   D.   Expansion by Incorporation of Additional Manufactured Home Lots . in
the event a nonconforming manufactured home park is expanded to include
additional manufactured home lots, such additional manufactured home lots shall
conform with the regulations set forth in this section.
8.    Development Plan Submission and Review. The following process shall apply
to all new manufactured home parks and to all nonconforming manufactured home
parks required to conform in whole or in part to the regulations set forth in
this section:
   A.   Concept Review. The first step in the approval process is a concept
review to discuss the applicant's plans. The concept review is an informal
discussion and review between the Zoning Administrator and the owner to discuss
land use and development concepts, applicable regulations, and other concerns
that may be raised.
   B.   Development Plan . The applicant shall thereafter prepare and submit a
development plan to the Planning and Zoning Commission including the following:
      (1)   Name of the manufactured home park.
      (2)   A north arrow, scale, and the size of the site to the nearest acre.
      (3)   Name(s) of the record owner(s) of the land.
      (4)   Existing zoning of the tract and the zoning of all adjacent
property.
      (5)   Existing topography of the site with contour intervals no greater
than five feet.
      (6)   Approximate location, size, and arrangement of proposed
manufactured home lots and other buildings on the site.
      (7)   Total number of manufactured home lots proposed and the density of
development.
      (8)   Proposed location of parking areas, an estimated parking ratio, and
the general arrangement of parking spaces and private drives within the
manufactured home park.
      (9)   Approximate location of any existing or proposed public streets
rights-of-way.
      (10)   Approximate location of existing sanitary sewers and water mains
within or adjacent to the site.
      (11)   Approximate location of fire hydrants within or adjacent to the
site for the purposes of demonstrating compliance with the provisions of
Section
165.14(9).
      (12)   Natural and modified drainage ways, proposed culverts, and
detention areas, if applicable, on the site.
      (13)   Existing waterways and/or wooded areas, and the approximate
location of the 100-year floodplain, if applicable.
      (14)   General description of proposed screening and landscaped areas on
the site.
      (15)   Applicable setbacks.
      (16)   Stages of development, if applicable.
      (17)   Legal description of the property.
      (18)   Signatures blocks for Planning and Zoning Commission and Council
approvals.
      (19)   Names and addresses of all property owners within 185 feet of the
manufactured home park.
      (20)   A fee to cover advertising costs.
   C.   Action on Development Plan.
      (1)   Following a duly noticed public hearing, the Planning and Zoning
Commission shall forward the development plan to Council with its
recommendation.
      (2)   Council, following a duly noticed public hearing, may approve,
approve conditionally, or deny the development plan.
      (3)   Following Council approval of the development plan, the applicant
may apply for and obtain applicable building permits for development of the
manufactured home park as outlined in the plan.
      (4)   Minor adjustments to an approved development plan may be authorized
by the Zoning Administrator or designee.
      (5)   Changes, other than those considered minor by the Zoning
Administrator or the designee, shall be submitted to the Planning and Zoning
Commission for its review. If the change is determined to be in substantial
compliance with the development plan, the Planning and Zoning Commission may
approve a revision to the development plan. If the change is a substantial
deviation from the intent of the approved development plan, a revised
development plan shall be required and shall be reviewed as a new proposal.
   D.   Withdrawal of Approval for Development Plans. From and after two years
following the date of approval of a development plan by Council, the Council
may, by a majority vote, withdraw approval of such development plan, provided
development has not commenced.
9.    Building Permits. No building permit shall be issued by any governing
official for the placement of any factory-built home or improvement to the land
or any manufactured home lot within a manufactured home park, until all
applicable requirements of this section have been fully satisfied.
10.    Inspection of Manufactured Home Parks. The Zoning Administrator, or
designee, shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or
public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions
relating to the enforcement of this section. It shall be the duty of the
manufactured home park management to give the Zoning Administrator, or
designee, free access to all manufactured home lots for the purpose of
inspection.
11.    Enforcement. The Zoning Administrator, or the designee, shall have the
authority to enforce this Zoning Code. A violation of any provision of this
section shall constitute a municipal infraction by the owner of the
manufactured home park and/or the owner of a factory-built home within the
manufactured home park as provided for in
Chapter 3.
12.    Conflicting Provisions. In the event of a conflict between the
provisions of this section and provisions elsewhere in the Zoning Code the
provisions of this section shall control.
165.15 GENERAL BUSINESS DISTRICT (B-1).
1.   District Regulations. The regulations set forth in this section or set
forth elsewhere in the Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are the
regulations in the General Business District (B-1).
2.    Use Regulations. Buildings and premises shall be used for any commercial
establishment in the Zoning Code whose primary purpose is retail trade, but
restricted in that any activities that could be labeled as manufacturing are
limited to those actions necessary to prepare the final product for retail
sale. Examples of permitted uses are:
   A.   General retail sales such as hardware, clothing, gifts, bakery items,
drug stores, notions, restaurants, taverns, appliances, radio, TV shops,
florists, and theaters.
   B.   General office uses such as banks, savings and loans, public offices,
attorneys, doctors, dentists, insurance, real estate, investment counseling,
and business offices.
   C.   General service businesses such as barber shops, beauty shops,
tailoring, gas stations parking lots, photo labs, photograph studios,
newspaper, media offices, and accountants.
   D.   Apartments, as accessory use to structure.
   E.   Car dealerships, agricultural machinery dealerships, other motorized or
RV vehicle dealerships, mobile home sales, car washes, auto body repair shops,
automotive repair shops, skating rinks, bowling, dance halls, and recreational
vehicle campsites.
   F.   Truck stops, drive-in restaurants, dry cleaners, motels, laboratories,
animal clinics, wholesale merchandise distributorship, veterinary clinics,
private, for profit schools, and private clubs.
   G.   Commercial greenhouse or nursery.
   H.   Wholesale merchandizing or storage warehouse. (Not including grain
storage.)
   I.   General service and repair establishments including dyeing or cleaning
works or laundry, plumbing and heating, printing, painting, upholstering, or
tinsmithing.
   J.   Compounding of cosmetics, toiletries, drugs, and pharmaceutical
products.
   K.   Outdoor advertising in accordance with Section
165.41 .
   L.   Accessory buildings.
   M.   Broadcasting station.
   N.   Any allowable use in R-2 Residential Districts.
3.    Parking Regulations. Off-street parking spaces shall be provided in
accordance with the requirements for specific uses set out in Section
165.38.
4.    Height Regulations. No building shall exceed six stories nor shall it
exceed 75 feet except as provided in Section
165.20.
5.    Area Regulations.
   A.   Yards.
      (1)   The front and rear yard regulations for dwellings are the same as
those in the R-1 Residential District. No front or rear yards for commercial
buildings are required except on the rear of a lot abutting an R-1 or R-
2 District, in which event a rear yard of not less than 30 feet shall be
provided.
      (2)   The side yard regulations for dwellings are the same as those in
the R-1 Residential District. No side yards for commercial buildings are
required except on the side of a lot abutting an R-1, R-2, or R-3 District, in
which event a side yard of not less than 30 feet shall be provided.
165.16 CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT (B-2).
1.    District Regulations. The regulations set forth in this section, or set
elsewhere in this Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are the
regulations in the Central Business District.
2.    Use Regulations. Any allowable use in B-1 General Business District.
3.    Parking Regulations.
   A.   Off-street parking spaces shall be provided in accordance with the
requirements for specific uses set out in Section
165.38 and
Chapter 69. The off-street parking requirements shall not apply to existing
commercial buildings in the Central Business District.
4.    Height Regulations. No building shall exceed six stories, nor shall it
exceed 75 feet except as provided in Section
165.20.
5.    Area Regulations.
   A.   No front or rear yards for commercial buildings are required except on
the rear of a lot abutting an R-1 or R-2 District, in which event a rear yard
of not less than two feet shall be provided.
   B.   The front, rear and side yard regulations for dwellings are the same as
those in the R- 1 Residential District .
165.17 LIGHT INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT (I-1).
1.   District Regulations. The regulations set forth in this section or set
forth elsewhere in this Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are the
regulations in the Light Industrial District (I-1).
2.    Use Regulations. The Light Industrial District is intended to provide a
low density buffer zone between heavy industrial and other uses. The types of
uses are intended to be warehousing, distributory, and light manufacturing. The
processing of raw materials intended for shipment to other locations for
further manufacturing is not allowed. Examples of permitted uses are:
   A.   Manufacture of dental, optical, drafting, musical, electronic,
recreation, or computer components or products.
   B.   Manufacture or storage of food products provided that no unprocessed
foods are used. Processing of flour would be permitted, processing of wheat
into flour would not. Manufacturing of dairy products from processed milk would
be allowed, processing of milk would not.
   C.   Manufacture or assembly of hardware, ornamental iron, sheet metal,
appliances, tools enameled products, provided no melting, smelting, or foundry
work is involved.
   D.   Manufacture or assembly of rugs, mattresses, and clothing.
   E.   Manufacture or assembly of boxes, crates, furniture, baskets, veneers,
or other wood products.
   F.   Any similar manufacturing or assembly process, provided that the work
does not involve any potential for the creation of or dispersement of
environmental pollutants.
   G.   Accessory buildings and uses.
   H.   Any allowable use in B-1 Business District.
3.    Parking Regulations. Refer to
Chapter 69 and Section
165.38.
4.    Height and Area Regulations.
   A.   Front Yards. Front yard setbacks for Light Industrial District shall be
30 feet or two feet of lineal setback for every one foot of building height,
whichever is greater.
      (1)   Front yard regulations for dwellings in a Light Industrial District
are the same as those in the R-1 Residential District.
   B.   Side Yards. Side yard setbacks for all industrial districts shall be
zero feet.
      (1)   Side yard regulations for dwellings in a Light Industrial District
are the same as those in the R-1 Residential District.
   C.   Rear Yard. Rear yard setbacks for all industrial districts shall be 30
feet.
      (1)   Rear yard regulations for dwellings in a Light Industrial District
are the same as those in the R-1 Residential District.
   D.   The front and rear yard regulations for commercial or non-industrial
use buildings in the Light Industrial District shall be the same as those
setbacks in the B-1 General Business District. No rear yards for commercial
buildings are required, except on the rear of a lot abutting an R-1 and R-
2 Residential District, in which event a rear yard of not less than 30 feet
shall be provided.
   E.   If a building contains both a business and industrial use in the Light
Industrial District, the industrial setback requirements shall prevail.
   F.   Existing business and commercial uses in existence in the Light
Industrial Districts at the time of the adoption of this Zoning Code shall be
allowed to continue and expand in their present location and shall not be
considered as non-conforming uses for the purposes of the enforcement of this
Zoning Code .
165.18 MIDDLE INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT (I-2).
1.    District Regulations. The regulations set forth in this section or set
forth elsewhere in this Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are the
regulations in the Middle Industrial District (I-2).
2.    Use Regulations. The Middle Industrial District is intended for those
purposes which may be deemed as having potential for regulated air, water,
ground, or noise pollution. Examples are:
   A.   Chemicals, petroleum, coal, and allied products .
   B.   Acid and derivatives.
   C.   Acetylene.
   D.   Ammonia.
   E.   Carbide.
   F.   Caustic soda.
   G.   Cellulose and cellulose storage.
   H.   Chlorine.
   I.   Coke oven products (including fuel gas) and coke oven products storage.
   J.   Creosote.
   K.   Distillation, manufacture, or refining of coal, tar, asphalt, wood, and
bones.
   L.   Processing of chemicals from one state to another or alteration of the
chemical composition of a substance.
   M.   Explosives (including ammunition and fireworks) and explosives storage.
   N.   Fertilizer (organic).
   O.   Fish oils and meal.
   P.   Glue, gelatin (animal).
   Q.   Hydrogen and oxygen.
   R.   Lamp black, carbon black, and bone black.
   S.   Nitrating of cotton or other materials.
   T.   Petroleum, gasoline and lubricating oil refining, and wholesale
storage.
   U.   Plastic materials and synthetic resins.
   V.   Potash.
   W.   Pyroxylin.
   X.   Turpentine and resin.
   Y.   Wells, gas, and oil.
   Z.   Clay, stone, and glass products.
   AA.   Brick, firebrick, refractories, and clay products (coal fired).
   BB.   Cement, lime, gypsum, or plaster of Paris.
   CC.   Minerals and earths; quarrying, extracting, grinding, crushing, and
processing.
   DD.   Metals and metal products.
   EE.   Aluminum powder and paint manufacture.
   FF.   Blast furnace, cupolas.
   GG.   Blooming mill.
   HH.   Metal and metal ores, reduction, refining, smelting, and alloying.
   II.   Scrap metal reduction or smelting.
   JJ.   Steel works and rolling mill (ferrous).
   KK.   Wood and paper products.
   LL.   Match manufacture.
   MM.   Wood pulp and fiber, reduction, and processing.
   NN.   Any allowable use in the Light Industrial District.
3.    Parking Regulations. Refer to
Chapter 69 and Section
165.38.
4.    Height and Area Regulations.
   A.   Front Yards. Front yard setbacks for Middle Industrial District shall
be 30 feet or two feet of lineal setback for every one foot of building height,
whichever is greater.
      (1)   Front yard regulations for dwellings in a Middle Industrial
District are the same as those in the R-1 Residential district.
   B.   Side Yards. Side yard setbacks for all Middle Industrial Districts
shall be zero feet.
      (1)   Side yard regulations for dwellings in a Middle Industrial District
are the same as those in the R-1 Residential District.
   C.   Rear Yard. Rear yard setbacks for all Middle Industrial District shall
be 30 feet.
      (1)   Rear yard regulations for dwellings in a Middle Industrial District
are the same as those in the R-1 Residential District.
   D.   The front and rear yard regulations for commercial/ non-industrial use
buildings in the Middle Industrial District shall be the same as those setbacks
in the B-1 General Business District. No rear yards for commercial buildings
are required, except on the rear of a lot abutting an R-1 and R-2 Residential
District, in which event a rear yard of not less than 30 feet shall be
provided.
   E.   If a building contains both a business and industrial use in the Middle
Industrial District, the industrial setback requirements shall prevail.
   F.   Existing business and commercial uses in existence in the Middle
Industrial District at the time of the adoption of this Zoning Code shall be
allowed to continue and expand in their present location and shall not be
considered as non-conforming uses for the purposes of the enforcement of this
Zoning Code.
5.    Area Regulations. Refer to
Chapter 165.
165.19 HEAVY INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT (I-3).
1.   District Regulations. The regulations set forth in this section or set
forth elsewhere in this Zoning Code, when referred to in this section, are the
regulations in the Heavy Industrial District (I-3).
2.    Use Regulations. The Heavy Industrial District is intended for those
purposes which may be deemed as having potential for regulated air, water,
ground, or noise pollution. Examples of uses are:
   A.   Manufacture of explosives (including ammunition and fireworks) and
explosives storage .
   B.   Rendering and storage of dead animals, garbage, or waste products .
   C.   Food and beverages .
   D.   Fat rendering .
   E.   Fish curing, packing, and storage .
   F.   Slaughter of animals .
   G.   Starch manufacture .
   H.   Unclassified industries and uses .
   I.   Hair, hides, and raw fur, curing, tanning, dressing, dyeing, and
storage .
   J.   Stockyards .
   K.   Junkyards and auto wrecking yards .
   L.   Processing or storage of radioactive materials done in accordance with
applicable federal and State regulations.
   M.   Buildings, structures, or enclosures for storage or processing of grain
or agricultural products not grown by the owner or tenant on the premises.
   N.   Any allowable use in the Middle Industrial District.
3.    Parking Regulations. Refer to
Chapter 69 and Section
165.38.
4.    Height and Area Regulations.
   A.   Front Yards. Front yard setbacks for Heavy Industrial District shall be
30 feet or two feet of lineal setback for every one foot of building height,
whichever is greater.
      (1)   Front yard regulations for dwellings in a Heavy Industrial District
are the same as those in the R-1 Residential District.
   B.   Side Yards. Side yard setbacks for all Heavy Industrial Districts shall
be zero feet.
      (1)   Side yard regulations for dwellings in a Heavy Industrial District
are the same as those in the R-1 Residential District.
   C.   Rear Yard. Rear yard setbacks for all Heavy Industrial District shall
be 30 feet.
      (1)   Rear yard regulations for dwellings in a Heavy Industrial District
are the same as those in the R-1 Residential District.
   D.   The front and rear yard regulations for commercial/ non-industrial use
buildings in the Heavy Industrial District shall be the same as those setbacks
in the B-1 General Business District. No rear yards for commercial buildings
are required, except on the rear of a lot abutting an R-1 and R-2 Residential
District, in which event a rear yard of not less than 30 feet shall be
provided.
   E.   If a building contains both a business and industrial use in the Heavy
Industrial District, the industrial setback requirements shall prevail.
   F.   Existing business and commercial uses in existence in the Heavy
Industrial Districts at the time of the adoption of this Zoning Code shall be
allowed to continue and expand in their present location and shall not be
considered as non-conforming uses for the purposes of the enforcement of this
Zoning Code.
5.    Area Regulations. Refer to
Chapter 165.
165.20 PUBLIC BUILDINGS AND INSTITUTIONS, HEIGHT OF.
Public, semipublic, or public service buildings, hospitals, institutions, or
schools, when permitted in a district, may be erected to a height not exceeding
60 feet if the building is set back from each yard line at least one foot for
each two feet of additional building height above the height limit otherwise
provided in the district in which the building is located.
165.21 HEIGHT OF CHIMNEYS, STEEPLES, AND LIKE STRUCTURES.
Chimneys, church steeples, cooling towers, elevator bulkheads, fire towers,
ornamental towers, spires, wireless towers, grain elevators, or necessary
mechanical appurtenances, are exempt from the height regulations as contained
herein.
165.22 ACCESSORY BUILDINGS, AREA, AND LOCATION.
1.    Location. Accessory structures shall not exceed in total 30 percent of
square footage area in rear yard, but no accessory building shall be closer
than 10 feet to the main building or closer than two feet to any lot line
(overhang or soffit included).
2.    Distance From the Main Building. If the accessory building is located
closer than 10 feet to the main building, then the accessory building shall be
regarded as part of the main building for purposes of determining side and rear
yard areas.
3.    Entrance From Alley. If the accessory building is a garage which is
entered from an alley and is not located closer than 10 feet to the main
building, then there shall be a rear yard of not less than 10 feet.
4.    Height Restriction. No accessory building in a residential district shall
be erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed, or structurally altered to
exceed 17 feet in height at the highest point from the grade level.
5.    Permit. A building permit must be issued prior to construction of any
accessory building or structure.
6.    Number of Accessory Buildings. No one accessory building will have a
square footage of more than 1200 square feet. Private garages must meet the
minimum principal structure front yard and side yard setback requirements.
7.    Materials. Accessory buildings and structures and garages shall be
constructed of materials comparable to the principal structure.
8.    Accessory Buildings, Use For Dwelling Purposes. No accessory building
shall be constructed upon a lot until the construction of the main building has
been actually commenced, and no accessory building shall be used for dwelling
purposes.
165.23 YARD UNOBSTRUCTED.
Every part of a required yard shall be open to the sky, unobstructed by any
structure, except for the projection of sills, belt course, and cornices which
do not exceed 12 inches. Ornamental structures, hedges, play structures (with
the exception of playhouses), mass plantings (non-trees), and handrails which
do not obstruct vision from or within the public right-of-way are permitted.
165.24 BASEMENT NOT OCCUPIED.
No basement or cellar shall be occupied for residential purposes until the
remainder of the building has been substantially completed.
165.25 PROJECTING STRUCTURES IN REAR YARD.
Open lattice enclosed fire escapes, fireproof outside stairways, balconies
opening upon fire towers, and the ordinary projections of chimneys and flues
into the rear yard are permitted.
165.26 TWO-FAMILY AND MULTIPLE-FAMILY DWELLINGS.
Two-family and multiple-family dwellings, where permitted, may be constructed
upon the same lot, or upon separate lots to provide for separate or divided
ownership, as follows:
1.   Where constructed upon the same lot, two-family dwellings or multiple-
family dwelling shall be considered as one building occupying one lot for
purposes of determining applicable yard and area requirements.
2.   Two-family dwellings and multiple-family dwellings may be constructed upon
separate lots to provide for separate or divided ownership of laterally
connected dwelling units, subject to the following requirements:
   A.   Each laterally connected dwelling unit shall have separate access and
separate utility services including without limitation gas, water, sewer, and
electricity.
   B.   Whether initially constructed on separate lots or subsequently
subdivided for purposes of establishing separate or divided ownership, each lot
upon which a laterally connected two-family dwelling or laterally connected
multiple-family dwelling is situated shall satisfy all applicable yard and lot
area requirements, provided that side yard setbacks shall not apply where
laterally connected dwelling units meet. Further, for purposes of determining
compliance with applicable yard and lot area requirements, laterally connected
dwellings on separate lots shall be considered as one building occupying one
lot.
   C.   Each lot upon which a laterally connected two-family dwelling or
multiple-family dwelling is situated shall be subject to restrictive covenants
of record with the Jackson County Recorder providing for the joint and uniform
maintenance and repair of the common wall(s) and all exterior portions of the
attached dwellings including but not limited to the roofs, siding, trim, doors,
driveways, sidewalks, and gutters and downspouts, so as to ensure a consistent
and uniform appearance. Copies of such restrictive covenants, as proposed,
shall be submitted together with the owner’s preliminary plat and/or final plat
for review pursuant to applicable subdivision regulations.
(Section 165.26 – Ord. 1243 – Dec. 24 Supp.)
165.27 GROUPS OF COMMERCIAL OR INDUSTRIAL BUILDINGS, OPEN SPACE REQUIRED.
Where a lot or tract is used for farming, a commercial, or industrial purpose,
more than one main building may be located upon the lot or tract, but only when
such buildings conform to all open space and setback requirements around the
lot for the district in which the lot or tract is located.
165.28 GROUPS OF RESIDENTIAL, INSTITUTIONAL, OR HOTEL BUILDINGS, OPEN SPACES
REQUIRED.
In the event that a lot is to be occupied by a group of two or more related
buildings to be used for multiple dwelling, institutional, motel or hotel
purposes, there may be more than one main building on the lot; provided
however, that the open space between buildings that are parallel shall have a
minimum dimension of 20 feet for one-story buildings, 30 feet for two-story
buildings and 40 feet for three or four-story buildings.
165.29 COURTS, MINIMUM DIMENSION REQUIRED.
Where an open space is more than 50 percent surrounded by a building, the
minimum width of the open space shall be at least 20 feet for one story
buildings, 30 feet for two-story buildings, and 40 feet for three or four-story
buildings.
165.30 SIDE YARDS FOR RESIDENTIAL USES ABOVE OTHER USES.
No side yards are required where dwelling units are erected above commercial
and industrial structures.
165.31 DOUBLE FRONTAGE, REQUIRED FRONT YARD ON BOTH STREETS.
Where lots have double frontage, the required front yard shall be provided on
both streets.
165.32 YARD REQUIREMENTS FOR CORNER LOTS.
The required side yard street side of a corner lot shall be the same as the
required front yard on such street, except that the building width shall not be
reduced to less than 32 feet and no accessory building shall project beyond the
required front yard on either street.
165.33 SIDE YARD WIDTH.
Whenever a lot at the effective date of this Zoning Code has a width of less
than 60 feet, the side yards may be reduced to a width of not less than 10
percent of the width of the lot, but in no instance shall it be less than five
feet.
165.34 FRONT YARDS, ADJUSTMENT IN RELATION TO EXISTING BUILDINGS.
1.    The front yards heretofore established shall be adjusted in the following
cases:
   A.   Where 40 percent or more of the frontage on the same side of a street
between two intersecting streets is developed with two or more buildings that
have, with a variation of five feet or less, a front yard greater in depth than
herein required, new buildings or additions to existing buildings shall not be
erected closer to the street than the front yard so established by the existing
building nearest the street line.
   B.   Where 40 percent or more of the frontage on one side of a street
between two intersecting streets is developed with two or more buildings that
have a front yard of less depth than herein required, then:
      (1)   Where a building or building addition is to be erected on a parcel
of land that is within 100 feet of existing buildings on both sides, the
minimum front yard shall be a line drawn between the two closest front corners
of the adjacent building on each side.
      (2)   Where a building or building addition is to be erected on a parcel
of land that is within 100 feet of an existing building on one side only, such
building or building addition may be erected as close to the street as the
existing adjacent building.
165.35 BED AND BREAKFAST FACILITIES.
The City wishes to limit the use of homes in the City for the accommodation of
overnight guests and allow the limited accommodation of overnight guests in
some homes in the R-2 General Residential District of the City. A bed and
breakfast home is viewed as a way for property owners to supplement the
renovation, upkeep, and maintenance on large historically significant homes.
Bed and breakfast homes are not intended to be commercial business located in a
residential setting. A bed and breakfast home shall comply with the following
restrictions and regulations:
1.    The bed and breakfast home shall be at least 50 years old as of the date
of adoption of this Zoning Code.
2.    The bed and breakfast home shall be the primary residence of the record
title holder of the real estate on which the home is located.
3.    The bed and breakfast home shall be in an R-2 General Residential
District.
4.    The bed and breakfast home shall have no more than six rooms designed for
overnight accommodation of guests.
5.    The bed and breakfast home shall have at least one off-street parking
space per overnight guest room plus one parking space for the owner-manager.
6.    The bed and breakfast home shall have no more than two signs, or more
than one sign per street frontage, or a sign that is larger than a total of two
square feet. Signs on bed and breakfast homes shall have no internal lighting.
Signs shall be attached to the bed and breakfast home or shall project from two
sides of the home less than one foot.
7.    The owner shall not allow the use of the bed and breakfast home for
serving of food or beverages to groups or individuals who are not overnight
guests during the 12 hours preceding or succeeding the service of food and
beverages.
8.    The owner shall not allow the use of the bed and breakfast home for
meetings of persons who are not overnight guests during the 12 hours preceding
or succeeding the meeting under the circumstance that a fee is charged.
9.    Overnight guests shall mean persons not related within the third degree
or not related by marriage, who remain at the bed and breakfast home for a
period of four hours after midnight of any 24-hour period.
10.    Bed and Breakfast Homes in Business Districts. Bed and breakfast homes
shall be a permitted use in the B-1 General Business District and the B-
2 General Business District and shall comply with the same sections of the
zoning ordinance that govern hotels and motels.
11.    Non-Conforming Use. Any bed and breakfast home that was granted a
Special Use Permit by the Board of Adjustment prior to the adoption of this
Zoning Code shall be classified as a non-conforming use and allowed to continue
to operate indefinitely within the limitations of the Special Use Permit but
without restriction to the expiration date stated in the permit and such
operation shall not constitute a violation of this Zoning Code. Specifically,
the existing bed and breakfast home located at 418 West Pleasant Street need
not be the primary residence of the record titleholders and may be managed by
an employee who resides in the home, shall be allowed to expand within the
existing structure to a total of nine rooms for guests, and shall provide one
off-street parking space for each guest room. The home also shall be available
for meetings of not to exceed 25 persons who need not be overnight guests and
the home shall be permitted to serve coffee, soft drinks, desserts,
refreshments, and snacks but not full luncheons or dinners to persons at the
meetings.
165.36 DECKS AND PORCHES.
A deck, porch, or enclosed porch area shall be considered as an extension of
the building and shall conform to the same setback requirements as the
building.
165.37 HANDICAP RAMPS.
Handicap ramps may project into a required yard as long as the platform area is
no greater than five feet in width, the ramp is no greater than four feet in
width, the ramp or platform area are not covered or enclosed and the ramp or
platform area do not block or obstruct vision from the right-of-way. All
handicap ramps must be approved by the Building Official.
165.38 OFF-STREET PARKING REGULATIONS.
1.    General Regulations. There shall be in all districts at the time of
erection adequate access to all spaces in conjunction with all land or building
uses shall be provided, prior to the issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy.
   A.   Off-street parking spaces may be provided within a rear or side yard
which is in excess of the minimum yard setback unless otherwise provided. Off-
street parking may be provided within a front yard which is in excess of the
minimum front yard setback in all commercial and industrial districts.
   B.   Off - street parking for other than a residential use shall be either
on the same lot or within 300 feet of the building it is intended to serve,
measured from the nearest point of the off-street parking lot. Ownership or
control of the parking lot shall be shown by the applicant.
   C.   Required residential off - street parking spaces shall consist of a
parking strip, bay, driveway, garage, or any combination thereof, and shall be
located on the premises which they are intended to serve.
   D.   The minimum required off - street parking spaces shall not be replaced
by any other use unless and until equal parking facilities are provided
elsewhere.
   E.   Off - street parking existing at the effective date of this Zoning Code
in connection with the operation of an existing building or use shall not be
reduced to an amount less than required for a similar new building.
   F.   Two or more buildings may collectively provide the required number of
parking spaces in which the required number of spaces shall not be less than
the sum of the requirements for the individual computed separately.
   G.   In the instance of dual function of off-street parking spaces where
operating hours of buildings do not overlap, the Board of Appeals may grant an
exception.
   H.   The storage of merchandise, motor vehicles for sale, or the repair of
motor vehicles is prohibited.
   I.   For those uses not specifically mentioned, the requirements for off-
street parking facilities shall be in accord with a use which the Planning and
Zoning Commission considers is similar in type.
   J.   When units or measurements determining the number of required parking
spaces result in the requirement of a fractional space, any fraction up to and
including one-half shall be disregarded and fractions over one-half shall
require one parking space.
   K.   For the purpose of computing the number of parking spaces required, the
definition of usable floor area shall govern.
2.    Minimum Number of Spaces. The minimum number of off-street parking spaces
by type shall be determined in accordance with the following schedule:
